parse.title: The Bloodhound, the Chef, and the Suffragette

links.*: The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide

wikitext.*:
'''''The Bloodhound, the Chef, and the Suffragette''''' is an unpublished comic play<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Tolkien Estate|The Tolkien Estate Limited]]|articleurl=https://www.tolkienestate.com/life/timeline-1892-1949/|articlename=Timeline (1892-1949) - The Tolkien Estate|dated=|website=Tolkien|accessed=7 October 2024}}, entry 1912</ref> written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] for his Incledon relatives during his vacation at [[Wikipedia:Barnt Green|Barnt Green]] in [[Wikipedia:Worcestershire|Worcestershire]]<ref name=guide>{{CG|RG}}, p. 75 (entry "Barnt Green (Worcestershire)")</ref> on Christmas in [[1912]]. In the performance of the play as the seasonal theatrical<ref name=drama>{{CG|RG}}, pp. 226-7 (entry "Drama - Tolkien as Performer")</ref>, Tolkien played "Professor Joseph Quilter"<ref name=Bio>{{B|IV}}, Chapter V: Oxford, p. 59</ref>, the lead role. The ties between the plot of the play and "Tolkien's own circumstances" regarding [[Edith Tolkien|Edith Bratt]] are obvious.<ref name=chronology>{{CG|C}}, p. 35 (entry "Christmas 1912")</ref>

{{Quote|'Professor Joseph Quilter, M.A., B.A., A.B.C., alias world-wide detective Sexton Q. Blake-Holmes, the Bloodhound', who is searching for a lost heiress named Gwendoline Goodchild. She meanwhile has fallen in love with a penniless student whom she meets while they are living in the same lodging-house, and she has to remain undiscovered by her father until her twenty-first birthday in two days' time, after which she will be free to marry.|Short summary by [[Humphrey Carpenter]]<ref name=Bio/>}}
